documents.name: Fuzzing
documents.text:
SUT/target: The System Under Test (SUT) is the piece of software that is being tested. It can either be a standalone application like a command-line program or a library.
Fuzzing/Fuzzer: Fuzz testing, also known as fuzzing, is an automated software testing method that supplies a SUT with invalid, unexpected, or random data as inputs. The program that implements the fuzzing algorithm is called a fuzzer.
Test case: A test case is the concrete input that is given to the testing harness. Usually, it is a string or bitstring. A test input can also be encoded in a more complex format like an abstract syntax tree.
(Testing/fuzzing) harness: A harness handles the test setup for a given SUT. The harness wraps the software and initializes it such that it is ready for executing test cases. A harness integrates a SUT into a testing environment.
libFuzzer harness: A harness that is compatible with the libFuzzer library. The term refers to the LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput function.
Fuzz test: A fuzz test consists of a fuzzing harness and the SUT. You might refer to a compiled binary that includes the harness and SUT as a fuzz test.
Fuzzing campaign: A fuzzing campaign is an execution of the fuzzer. A fuzzing campaign starts when the fuzzer starts testing and stops when the fuzzing procedure is stopped.
Corpus: The evolving set of test cases. During a fuzzing campaign, the corpus usually grows as new test cases are discovered.
Seed Corpus: Fuzzing campaigns are usually bootstrapped using an initial set of test cases. This set is also called a seed corpus. Each test case of the corpus is called a seed.
Fuzzing engine/runtime: The fuzzing engine/runtime is part of the fuzzer that is executed when the fuzzing starts. It orchestrates the fuzzing process.
Instrumentation: The act of instrumenting a program involves adding non-functional changes in order to retrieve data from it or making it more secure/robust.
Code coverage: A metric to measure the degree to which the source code of a program is executed.

documents.name: Tech News
documents.text:
the corporate VC arm of health insurer CSS, invests in high-growth start-ups that are advancing healthcare with digital technologies. It particularly promotes solutions that create sustainable added value for health insurers and their customers.

Thanks to the support of CSS, the SwissHealth Ventures digital health fund has now doubled its volume from CHF 50 million to CHF 100 million. The additional funds will enable around twelve further start-up investments in the coming years. SwissHealth Ventures operates with an evergreen structure, which means that the returns flow back into the fund and are available for further investments.

SwissHealth Ventures plans to use the fresh funds to invest in two to three new digital health start-ups each year. It will invest jointly with other European venture capitalists with the aim of supporting the start-ups in their market entry in Switzerland through the health insurance company's expertise and network. "We believe that the digital health sector will grow at an even faster pace in the coming years and is set to become even more attractive within the healthcare industry. Technological innovations, AI and the trend towards outpatient treatment are contributing significantly to this," explains Jonathan Fraser, Head of Corporate Venturing, SwissHealth Ventures. This represents a strategic opportunity for CSS: it gains early access to leading start-ups and innovative solutions that can be integrated into its offerings.

SwissHealth Ventures has invested in twelve companies to date – four of them from Switzerland – and two digital health funds. The results are impressive: the twelve existing portfolio companies have created over 3,200 jobs and are financially successful. ‘More than 330,000 CSS members have already used one of their services, giving them access to innovations that improve their lives and make the healthcare system more sustainable,’ explains Fraser. One example is Flow Neuroscience from Sweden: CSS was the first health insurance company worldwide to reimburse Flow's new therapy for the treatment of depression, which is already being used in 16 Swiss clinics today.

SwissHealth Ventures invests in digital business models in the healthcare sector in a growth phase with a monthly turnover of approximately CHF 100,000 or more. In addition to start-ups that offer effective benefits for CSS policyholders, companies that make the healthcare system more efficient are also eligible. A good example is Lyfegen from Basel. Jonathan Fraser says: ‘This platform helps us negotiate fair prices with pharmaceutical companies. This year alone, we have saved CHF 3.5 million as a result.’

documents.name: Digital Media
documents.text:
[00:00:00] Let’s be honest: if you’ve been on the internet,
[00:00:02] you’ve probably seen porn.
[00:00:03] Whether you went looking for it,
[00:00:05] a friend shoved a video under your nose,
[00:00:06] or you got a sketchy DM,
[00:00:08] it’s hard not to come across porn in our extremely online world.
[00:00:12] Either way, your first encounter with porn might have piqued your curiosity.
[00:00:15] Or it might have even disturbed you.
[00:00:17] It’s okay—we’re gonna unpack all of that together.
[00:00:20] Hi! I’m Shan Boodram, and this is Crash Course Sex Ed.
[00:00:23] [THEME MUSIC]
[00:00:27] Head’s up: in today’s video, we’ll be talking about a sensitive topic,
[00:00:31] including sexual assault and descriptions of certain kinds of sex acts.
[00:00:35] So please keep that in mind and take care when watching.
[00:00:37] We learn about sex from a lot of different sources.
[00:00:40] But nobody seems to want to admit that for a lot of people,
[00:00:43] one of their biggest teachers is pornography:
[00:00:45] videos, films, magazines, and other forms of media that are meant for sexual arousal.
[00:00:50] No matter what popped into your head when I first said “porn,”
[00:00:53] the word has a pretty broad definition,
[00:00:55] because what’s considered arousing can really vary from person to person.
[00:00:59] In a Supreme Court case about which sexual material was obscene enough to censor,
[00:01:03] one of the justices said porn was hard to define,
[00:01:06] but “I know it when I see it.”
[00:01:09] Whatever it is, porn is a part of our society.
[00:01:11] Like, one survey from 2022 found that seventy-three percent of
[00:01:15] teenagers may have seen porn online,
[00:01:17] many before the age of thirteen,
[00:01:19] despite the rise of age-restriction laws that require viewers to be eighteen or older.
[00:01:24] Teen Shan: Well I definitely don’t watch porn.
[00:01:26] Shan: Girl, I’m you. I know you’re lying.
[00:01:29] But I don’t blame you.
[00:01:30] ‘Cause here’s the thing:
[00:01:31] The way sex ed classes and the adults in our lives talk about porn
[00:01:34] — if they do at all —
[00:01:36] is often full of shame.
[00:01:37] And that leaves people with a sense that they shouldn’t ask questions.
[00:01:40] But it turns out, one of the best ways
[00:01:42] to responsibly engage with porn… is by getting curious.
[00:01:46] The first thing to know?
[00:01:47] Images that we might consider pornographic today have been around forever.
[00:01:50] Peruvian sex pots sculpted fifteen hundred years ago,
[00:01:53] frescoes from 1st-century Pompeii,
[00:01:56] 17th-century erotic Japanese paintings.
[00:01:58] Images of naked people doing sexy stuff have been around for a long time.
[00:02:02] Although, whether an image was considered
[00:02:04] pornographic generally depended on the viewer’s cultural background.
[00:02:07] European archaeologists were often the ones claiming these images were “obscene”
[00:02:11] without understanding their cultural context.
[00:02:13] And people haven’t just used explicit material to get all hot and bothered.
[00:02:17] In 18th-century Europe, they also used it to spread illicit information about
[00:02:21] contraception and women’s sexual freedom,
[00:02:23] and to poke fun at the aristocracy.
[00:02:25] Add this to the fact that porn was seen as depraved,
[00:02:28] and you can see why its creators were often punished with jail time.
[00:02:31] But that didn’t stop people from making more.
[00:02:33] As time went on, and photography and film were invented,
[00:02:36] visual porn became super popular.
[00:02:38] And these days, the internet is home to more sexually explicit material than your
[00:02:42] great-great-great-great-grandparents could have ever imagined.
[00:02:47] So yes, porn is not new.
[00:02:49] But what is new is the sheer amount and accessibility of it that we get from the internet.
[00:02:54] And that comes with some benefits… and some downsides.
[00:02:57] On the positive side, consuming porn
[00:02:59] —and even sexy scenes in regular ol’ TV shows and movies—
[00:03:02] may help destigmatize sex,
[00:03:04] and provide people with a space to explore their sexuality,
[00:03:07] especially if information about that kind of thing isn’t available in their IRL communities.
[00:03:11] This can be particularly true for members of the LGBTQ+ community.
[00:03:16] Remember how the “Q” can stand for “questioning?”
[00:03:18] Porn can help those folks figure out what they find sexy.
[00:03:21] In fact, because education about anything but penis-in-vagina sex is hard to come by,
[00:03:26] young LGBTQ+ people often learn the nuts and bolts of sex from porn.
[00:03:30] Ultimately, everybody’s relationship with porn is different.
[00:03:34] But truth be told, porn isn’t all fun and games, either.
[00:03:37] One of the main reasons? Most of it is not realistic.
[00:03:40] No matter how amateur the footage looks,
[00:03:42] the vast majority of video porn is staged for the screen,
[00:03:45] and the people involved are performers.
[00:03:47] But that can be hard to remember.
[00:03:49] If we just accept what happens in those scenes at face value,
[00:03:52] it can lead to us picking up warped ideas about what sex should look like —
[00:03:56] or what we should look like.
[00:03:58] Multiple studies have found that the usually thin, hairless women
[00:04:01] and chiseled dudes in porn can make young people feel bad about their own bodies,
[00:04:05] just like airbrushed Instagram models or gym bro TikTokers can.
[00:04:09] And when it comes to the experience of sex —
[00:04:11] in pornographic videos, performers often fake orgasms,
[00:04:15] because again, they’re performing.
[00:04:18] Teen Shan: WHAT?! They fake orgasms?
[00:04:20] I mean, I wouldn’t know. I don’t watch porn.
[00:04:23] Shan: Mmmk. Yeah, Teen Shan.
[00:04:25] They do fake orgasms.
[00:04:26] And this can give viewers the false idea that
[00:04:28] everyone’s going to respond the same way to certain sex acts,
[00:04:31] and make them wonder if something’s wrong when it doesn’t play out that way.
[00:04:35] And one of the most unrealistic parts of most
[00:04:37] porn videos is that they don’t talk about the important stuff.
[00:04:41] A lot of the time, they’re just naked people on a bed, and they start doing stuff.
[00:04:45] No consent. No communication about desires.
[00:04:47] And no protection.
[00:04:48] People with penises often don’t wear condoms in porn—
[00:04:51] let alone have a conversation about wearing one.
[00:04:53] But in reality, talking to each other is one of the key ways to have good sex.
[00:04:58] Many researchers and educators have also raised red flags about the amount
[00:05:01] of violence and non-consensual aggression on popular porn sites,
[00:05:05] especially because they can reflect harmful attitudes about women,
[00:05:08] and especially women of color.
[00:05:10] In a 2020 study of over four thousand porn scenes,
[00:05:13] thirty-five to forty-five percent showed violence,
[00:05:16] with women being the target ninety-seven percent of the time.
[00:05:19] Another study showed that Black women were even
[00:05:22] more likely than white women to be shown as the victims of violence,
[00:05:25] and Black men were shown as aggressors more often than white men.
[00:05:28] And the thing about the internet is,
[00:05:29] you don’t even have to click on these videos
[00:05:31] to see thumbnails and titles that use racial stereotypes and misogyny.
[00:05:36] Historically, exploitation of performers has been a major part of the industry, too.
[00:05:40] This is a complex issue that we won’t dive into today,
[00:05:43] but know that many people who watch porn are getting more interested in how to do so ethically.
[00:05:48] Now, as far as the research goes,
[00:05:51] there’s no conclusive evidence about whether watching violent
[00:05:53] or misogynistic porn makes someone more likely to act that way offline.
[00:05:58] Some research, including a survey from 2019, found that respondents who viewed
[00:06:02] violent porn were more likely to have perpetrated sexual violence,
[00:06:06] but that doesn’t necessarily mean one causes the other.
[00:06:09] And emerging research, including one study that surveyed almost
[00:06:12] five thousand American college students, has found that choking
[00:06:15] —an act popularized by video porn and other media like “Euphoria”—
[00:06:19] has increased among young adults,
[00:06:21] despite the fact that it’s not a safe thing to do, even when it’s consensual.
[00:06:26] But long-term research is also sparse,
[00:06:27] and different definitions of porn make it hard to compare findings.
[00:06:31] And when it comes to misogyny, a lot of studies are at odds.
[00:06:34] Some say that watching porn is correlated
[00:06:36] with having sexist attitudes, while some say the opposite.
[00:06:39] Also, scientists still don’t really know what high exposure to porn does to our brains.
[00:06:44] If you want to learn more about the research that does exist,
[00:06:46] you can visit our friends over at SciShow.
[00:06:49] One way or another, though, porn is still… everywhere.
[00:06:52] So what do we do with that?
[00:06:54] The key is to think critically about what we see in porn,
[00:06:57] and to make smart decisions about it:
[00:06:59] a little thing called porn literacy.
[00:07:01] Porn literacy is part of sexual literacy,
[00:07:04] the critical thinking skills needed to have good sexual health.
[00:07:07] And it’s not all that different from media literacy.
[00:07:09] It involves a lot of the same concepts and skills you’d use
[00:07:12] to identify the biases behind a news article,
[00:07:15] or figure out if a photo was made by AI.
[00:07:18] It also involves unpacking the assumptions we adopt from porn so that we don’t
[00:07:22] spread misinformation or bring harmful behaviors or ideas into our sex lives.
[00:07:26] Like, if you don’t see people wearing condoms or talking about contraception or STIs in porn,
[00:07:32] what message is that sending you?
[00:07:34] So, here are some questions you can ask yourself when
[00:07:36] you come across a piece of pornographic media:
[00:07:39] One: How does this make me feel?
[00:07:42] Two: What is this trying to get me to think about sex or people?
[00:07:46] Three: What about this might not be true to life?
[00:07:50] Four: What’s missing from this piece of media?
[00:07:53] And five: What sources of information can I trust about the stuff I’m seeing here?
[00:07:58] That last question might be the trickiest —
[00:08:00] but it’s an important one.
[00:08:02] We all know we shouldn’t believe everything you see on the internet,
[00:08:05] but that is where we get a lot of our information.
[00:08:08] And some online sources are better than others.
[00:08:10] Some reference research from doctors, sex therapists, and scientific journals.
[00:08:14] While others… well, you’ve probably seen some of those TikToks.
[00:08:18] Also, it’s worth noting that these
[00:08:20] critical-thinking skills don’t just apply to explicit videos.
[00:08:24] You can use these questions to analyze any information about sex you encounter,
[00:08:28] from TV and movies to fanfiction and spicy romance novels.
[00:08:31] Or my personal favorite medium: audio erotica.
[00:08:35] ‘Cause the thing is: there’s nothing wrong with
[00:08:38] wanting to explore your sexuality or responsibly seek out pleasure.
[00:08:41] But like anything else,
[00:08:43] it’s important to make sure we do so in a way that’s healthy, safe, and mindful.
[00:08:48] Ultimately, not everybody watches porn on the regular,
[00:08:50] and it’s certainly not a requirement for a happy sex life.
[00:08:53] But for those who enjoy it,
[00:08:55] it’s important to think critically about what’s being portrayed.
[00:08:57] Because in the end, porn is designed to arouse and entertain.
[00:09:01] But it’s not meant to educate—for that, you’ve got things like Crash Course.
[00:09:05] Coming up next, we’re talking all about orgasms.
[00:09:08] See you then.
[00:09:08] This episode of Crash Course Sex Ed was produced
[00:09:11] in partnership with the Kinsey Institute at Indiana University.
[00:09:14] If you are interested in learning more,
[00:09:16] visit their website for resources that explore the topics we discussed in the video today.
[00:09:21] Thank you for watching this episode,
[00:09:22] which was filmed at our studio in Indianapolis and
[00:09:24] was made with the help of all these sexually literate people.
[00:09:27] If you want to help keep Crash Course free for everyone, forever,
[00:09:31] you can join the community on Patreon.

SUT/target: The System Under Test (SUT) is the piece of software that is being tested. It can either be a standalone application like a command-line program or a library.
Fuzz test: A fuzz test consists of a fuzzing harness and the SUT. You might refer to a compiled binary that includes the harness and SUT as a fuzz test.

the corporate VC arm of health insurer CSS, invests in high-growth start-ups that are advancing healthcare with digital technologies. It particularly promotes solutions that create sustainable added value for health insurers and their customers.

SwissHealth Ventures plans to use the fresh funds to invest in two to three new digital health start-ups each year. It will invest jointly with other European venture capitalists with the aim of supporting the start-ups in their market entry in Switzerland through the health insurance company's expertise and network. "We believe that the digital health sector will grow at an even faster pace in the coming years and is set to become even more attractive within the healthcare industry. Technological innovations, AI and the trend towards outpatient treatment are contributing significantly to this," explains Jonathan Fraser, Head of Corporate Venturing, SwissHealth Ventures. This represents a strategic opportunity for CSS: it gains early access to leading start-ups and innovative solutions that can be integrated into its offerings.

SwissHealth Ventures invests in digital business models in the healthcare sector in a growth phase with a monthly turnover of approximately CHF 100,000 or more. In addition to start-ups that offer effective benefits for CSS policyholders, companies that make the healthcare system more efficient are also eligible. A good example is Lyfegen from Basel. Jonathan Fraser says: ‘This platform helps us negotiate fair prices with pharmaceutical companies. This year alone, we have saved CHF 3.5 million as a result.’
Code coverage: A metric to measure the degree to which the source code of a program is executed.

Fuzzing engine/runtime: The fuzzing engine/runtime is part of the fuzzer that is executed when the fuzzing starts. It orchestrates the fuzzing process.
Instrumentation: The act of instrumenting a program involves adding non-functional changes in order to retrieve data from it or making it more secure/robust.

Corpus: The evolving set of test cases. During a fuzzing campaign, the corpus usually grows as new test cases are discovered.
Seed Corpus: Fuzzing campaigns are usually bootstrapped using an initial set of test cases. This set is also called a seed corpus. Each test case of the corpus is called a seed.

(Testing/fuzzing) harness: A harness handles the test setup for a given SUT. The harness wraps the software and initializes it such that it is ready for executing test cases. A harness integrates a SUT into a testing environment.
libFuzzer harness: A harness that is compatible with the libFuzzer library. The term refers to the LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput function.

Fuzzing/Fuzzer: Fuzz testing, also known as fuzzing, is an automated software testing method that supplies a SUT with invalid, unexpected, or random data as inputs. The program that implements the fuzzing algorithm is called a fuzzer.

SwissHealth Ventures has invested in twelve companies to date – four of them from Switzerland – and two digital health funds. The results are impressive: the twelve existing portfolio companies have created over 3,200 jobs and are financially successful. ‘More than 330,000 CSS members have already used one of their services, giving them access to innovations that improve their lives and make the healthcare system more sustainable,’ explains Fraser. One example is Flow Neuroscience from Sweden: CSS was the first health insurance company worldwide to reimburse Flow's new therapy for the treatment of depression, which is already being used in 16 Swiss clinics today.
